nodes.userMessage: Hey. I don't really know why I'm writing to you. I have no one else to talk to, actually.

choices.text: I'm here. Whatever the reason, you can talk to me. What's going on?
No one? You must have some family or friends somewhere?

nodes.userMessage: I don't know how to explain it. I feel invisible. Like, if I disappeared tomorrow, no one would notice for weeks.

choices.text: That feeling of invisibility is painful. How long have you been feeling this way?
Maybe it's just an impression. People are often more attentive than we think.

nodes.userMessage: My family is far away and we don't really talk anymore. Friends... I had some, before. But people always end up leaving.

choices.text: It hurts when connections fade. Do you know what happened with your friends?
If everyone leaves, maybe you should ask yourself why.

nodes.userMessage: Years, I think. It started slowly. A friend who moved away, another who got into a relationship and disappeared... And one day you find yourself alone.

choices.text: Loneliness is insidious. It creeps in without you noticing. Have you tried to rebuild connections?
What about work? Do you have colleagues you get along with?

nodes.userMessage: No, it's not just an impression. The last time someone texted me without me reaching out first was 3 months ago.

choices.text: 3 months... That's a long time. It must be exhausting to always be the one initiating contact.
Have you tried joining groups or activities? That's how you meet people.

nodes.userMessage: Nothing dramatic. Just life. They had kids, demanding jobs. And I just stayed there, waiting for someone to think of me.

choices.text: It's hard watching others move forward while you feel stuck. Do you feel left behind?
Friendships require effort from both sides. Did you tell them you felt neglected?

nodes.userMessage: ... Wow. Thanks for the stab. I knew it was a bad idea to talk.
I've tried. Friendship apps, events... But I can't seem to form real connections. Everything stays superficial.

choices.text: Real connections take time. It's frustrating when you need connection now. What do you think is blocking you?
Maybe you're setting the bar too high? Sometimes light friendships have value too.

nodes.userMessage: I work fully remote. I don't see anyone all week. Sometimes I don't speak out loud for 4-5 days straight.

choices.text: 4-5 days without speaking... That's extreme isolation. How do you cope?
Remote work can be very isolating. Have you considered working from a caf√© or coworking space sometimes?

nodes.userMessage: Exhausting, yes. At some point I stopped trying. And now, nothing. Complete silence.

choices.text: You tested people and they failed. It makes sense to protect yourself. But silence isn't a solution either.
Maybe those people weren't the right ones. That doesn't mean no one can be there for you.

nodes.userMessage: I tried a pottery class once. Lasted 3 sessions. I couldn't talk to people, I felt like I was weird.

choices.text: Feeling weird in a group is often social anxiety. Have you always struggled with that?
3 sessions is short. Sometimes it takes more time to fit into a group.

nodes.userMessage: Left behind, yes. Like I'm not interesting enough for people to make the effort.

choices.text: What you feel isn't reality. People are often absorbed in their own lives, not because you lack interest.
You find yourself uninteresting? Where does that thought come from?

nodes.userMessage: No. I'm afraid of coming across as the annoying girl who's begging for attention.

choices.text: Expressing a need isn't begging for attention. It's being honest. Real friends can hear that.
If you don't say anything, how can they know you're hurting?

nodes.userMessage: I don't know. Maybe I'm too in my head. I analyze everything, wondering if I'm saying the right things, if I'm boring...

choices.text: That hyper-vigilance is exhausting and prevents you from being yourself. Have you ever talked to a therapist about it?
Everyone doubts themselves a bit socially. But if it paralyzes you, it might be social anxiety.

nodes.userMessage: Light friendships... I've had those. But they don't fill the void. I need someone who really knows me.

choices.text: That need for deep connection is human. But it requires vulnerability. Can you open up to people?
Deep friendships are built over time. Sometimes they start superficial.

nodes.userMessage: I don't really cope. I pretend. I work, I eat, I sleep. But there's nothing inside anymore.

choices.text: What you're describing sounds like depression. Have you thought about seeing someone?
That inner emptiness is an alarm signal. Your body is telling you something needs to change.

nodes.userMessage: I've thought about it. But the idea of sitting alone in a caf√© surrounded by people who know each other... That stresses me out even more.

choices.text: I understand. Being alone in public can amplify the feeling of isolation. What about starting with online spaces?
Social stress can be worked on. Little by little. A caf√©, 30 minutes, just for yourself.

nodes.userMessage: I know it's not a solution. But I don't have the energy to make the first move anymore. I've been disappointed too many times.

choices.text: Emotional exhaustion is real. Maybe the first step isn't toward others, but toward yourself. Taking care of yourself first.
What if the first step was just talking to a professional? Not for advice, just to be heard.

nodes.userMessage: The right ones... I don't even know what that looks like anymore. I've forgotten what it's like to have someone think of you.

choices.text: You deserve to have that. The fact that you haven't had it doesn't mean it doesn't exist for you.
Sometimes we need to relearn how to receive. When you've been alone for a long time, you forget how to accept attention.

nodes.userMessage: Yes, always. As a kid I was already the weird girl who stayed in her corner at recess.

choices.text: Those childhood patterns leave marks. But it doesn't mean you're doomed to stay alone.
Social anxiety can be treated. With a therapist, you could work on it.

nodes.userMessage: Maybe. But each session was torture. I felt like everyone was judging me.

choices.text: That constant feeling of being judged is anxiety. Others probably aren't thinking about you as much as you believe.
Maybe group activities aren't for you. There are other ways to meet people.

nodes.userMessage: Maybe you're right. But it doesn't change the result: I'm alone.

choices.text: Yes, you're alone right now. But that can change. What would help you most, do you think?
Current loneliness isn't a life sentence. It's a situation, not an identity.

nodes.userMessage: I don't know. I've always felt like I'm not enough. Not funny enough, not pretty enough, not interesting enough.

choices.text: Those thoughts come from somewhere. Did someone make you feel that way, or is it you judging yourself?
Social impostor syndrome. You're comparing yourself to an ideal version that doesn't exist.

nodes.userMessage: You're right. But I'm so afraid of rejection that I prefer silence.

choices.text: Silence protects you from rejection, but it also deprives you of connection. That's a high price.
Fear of rejection can be worked on. With time and maybe some support.

nodes.userMessage: A therapist... I've thought about it. But talking about my loneliness to a stranger paid to listen, it's kind of ironic, isn't it?

choices.text: I get the irony. But a therapist isn't a friend, they're a tool to help you make friends. It's different.
Sometimes we need a neutral space to untangle what's blocking us. It's not cheating.

nodes.userMessage: Social anxiety... So it has a name. I thought I was just bad with people.

choices.text: You're not bad, you have something that can be worked on. Many people live with it and learn to manage it.
Putting a name on it is already a first step. It means it's known and there are solutions.

nodes.userMessage: Open up? No. I'm too afraid they'll use my weaknesses against me. Or leave once they really know me.

choices.text: That fear protects you but also isolates you. Real connections are built on shared vulnerability.
Has someone done that to you before? Used your secrets against you?

nodes.userMessage: I know. But I don't have the patience anymore. I'm 27 and I feel like I've already failed at everything.

choices.text: 27 is young. You haven't failed anything, you're just in a low point. It can change.
The feeling of having failed at everything, that's depression talking. Not reality.

nodes.userMessage: See someone... Yeah, maybe. But I don't even have the energy to find a therapist and make an appointment.

choices.text: That's normal when you're at rock bottom. You could start with an online booking site, 5 minutes. Just that.
If it's too hard, you could call a helpline first. Crisis lines, support hotlines... Just to talk.

nodes.userMessage: Something needs to change... But what? I feel stuck.

choices.text: Sometimes the first change is just accepting you need help. You did that by writing to me.
One small step. Just one. Not changing everything at once. Just one thing different tomorrow.

nodes.userMessage: Online? Like forums or Discord servers?

choices.text: Yes, exactly. There are communities around your interests. It's less intimidating than face to face.
It can be a first step. Online connections can become real over time.

nodes.userMessage: 30 minutes... That seems doable. Maybe I can try.

choices.text: That's all it takes. One small step. And if it's too hard, you leave. No pressure.
Bring a book or your phone. It gives you something to do and removes the pressure to talk.

nodes.userMessage: Taking care of myself... I've forgotten how. I'm just surviving.

choices.text: Surviving is already a lot. But you deserve more. A small pleasure, just for you, what would that be?
Start with the basics: eat something you like, take a hot shower, go outside for 10 minutes. Little by little.

nodes.userMessage: A situation, not an identity... I never saw it that way.

choices.text: You're not 'a lonely person.' You're a person going through a period of loneliness. It's different.
Situations change. You can change too. Nothing is set in stone.

nodes.userMessage: Relearn how to receive... It's true that when someone is nice to me, I get suspicious.

choices.text: That's normal protection after being disappointed. But it also prevents you from accepting the good.
Distrust can be unlearned. Slowly, with people who prove they're reliable.

nodes.userMessage: Not doomed... I'd like to believe you. But it's been so long.

choices.text: Time spent alone doesn't predict time to come. People find connections at any age.
Believing is hard when you've been disappointed. But trying again, with help this time?

nodes.userMessage: I know it's in my head. But it doesn't change what I feel.

choices.text: Emotions are real even if the thoughts causing them are distorted. That's why a therapist can help.
Knowing it's in your head is already a form of lucidity. That's a good starting point.

nodes.userMessage: What would help? Just someone who thinks of me. Who texts me for no reason.

choices.text: That's a simple and deep need. While waiting to find that person, you can be that person for yourself.
What if you were that person for someone else? Sometimes giving what we want to receive helps.

nodes.userMessage: My mother, I think. She always compared me to my sister. 'Why aren't you like her?'

choices.text: Those words leave marks. You internalized her gaze. But it was her problem, not your truth.
Constant comparison destroys self-esteem. You deserve to see yourself through your own eyes, not hers.

nodes.userMessage: An ideal version that doesn't exist... Yeah. I'm always comparing myself to others on social media.

choices.text: Social media shows the best of others, not their reality. It's a rigged comparison.
What if you reduced your time on social media? It might help quiet that critical voice.

nodes.userMessage: A high price... Yes. But rejection hurts even more.

choices.text: Rejection hurts, but it passes. Permanent loneliness settles in. It's a long-term calculation.
What if you started with small risks? People where rejection would have less impact?

nodes.userMessage: Ok. I'm going to look for a therapist. It scares me but I can't stay like this. Thanks.
Thanks. It felt good to talk. I feel a little less alone, strangely.
Shared vulnerability... It's scary. But maybe I should try. Thanks.
Yes, an ex-friend. She told my secrets to everyone. Since then I don't trust anyone.
A low point... I hope you're right. Thanks for listening.
Depression... Maybe. I'll think about it. Thanks.
5 minutes on a booking site. Ok. I can do that. Thanks.
A helpline... I didn't know those existed. Maybe I'll call. Thanks.
You're right, I wrote to you. That's already something. Thanks for responding.
One small step. Ok. I'll try. Thanks for this conversation.
I'll look for a Discord about something I'm interested in. Thanks for the idea.
Ok, I'll try the caf√© tomorrow. With a book. Thanks.
A small pleasure... I'll order something I like tonight. Thanks.
A period, not an identity. I'll try to remember that. Thanks.
Unlearning distrust... That'll take time. But thanks.
Connections at any age... I hope so. Thanks for listening.
Be that person for myself... It's sad but you're right. Thanks.
Give what I want to receive... I'll text someone. Thanks.
It was her problem, not my truth... That feels good to hear. Thanks.
Reduce social media... Yeah, I should. Thanks for everything.
A long-term calculation... You're right. Permanent loneliness is worse. Thanks.
Small risks first. Ok. I'll try. Thanks. üíô
